Yes, you can use the `pandas` `shift()` function to create new columns in your dataframe for the `a`, `b`, and `c` values at time `t+1`. The `shift()` function will shift the values in the `a`, `b`, and `c` columns by one time step, so that the values at time `t+1` will be in the new columns you create.

Here is an example of how you could use the `shift()` function to create the new columns:
```
# create new columns in the dataframe for the 'a', 'b', and 'c' values at time 't+1'
df['a_t+1'] = df['a'].shift(1)
df['b_t+1'] = df['b'].shift(1)
df['c_t+1'] = df['c'].shift(1)
```
Once you have created the new columns, you can train your model using the updated dataframe with the additional `a`, `b`, and `c` columns. This will allow your model to use the information from the `a`, `b`, and `c` values at both time `t` and time `t+1` to make more accurate predictions.

Here is an example of how you could train your model using the updated dataframe:
```
# train your model using the updated dataframe with the additional 'a', 'b', and 'c' columns
model.train(df)
```
Note that the specific steps you need to take will depend on the details of your data and your model. This is just one example of how you could approach this problem.
